title: YEAR IN REVIEW 2025
body_text:
Before we say goodbye to 2025 and welcome in 2026, it is a tradition for the Quad Community Press to look back at some of the most memorable moments this past year.
In 2025, pages were filled with a variety of news, government meetings, events, sports, businesses, the arts and much more. Some of the most memorable stories are the ones that featured local residents—Centennial Cougar athletes found success in their respective sports; the Circle Pines 75th anniversary celebration, Fete des Lacs and Blue Heron Days in Lino Lakes brought the community together for multiple weekends of summer fun; and many in the community had a very busy year.
JANUARY
Centennial school district looks to expand
The Centennial School District is planning for the future by creating a 10-year facilities and enrollment plan based on student enrollment trends, educational capacity relative to providing current and future programming facility space for co-curricular opportunities. The district was looking to build at 1687 Westview Street in Centerville, also known as the LaLonde property. Centerville Elementary would undergo construction to include new amenities such as two extra music rooms, a new gym and learning common areas.
McCall notches 1,000 points
During her senior season Autumn McCall celebrated her 1,000th career point during a win against Osseo. McCall committed to play basketball at the University of St. Thomas, a division 1 program.
Centerville welcomes new mayor, city officials
The city of Centerville welcomed not only the new year, but new city officials and a new mayor. Nancy Golden was sworn into office as the mayor of Centerville. Council Members Russ Koski and David Kubat took the oath of office to begin their four-year terms, and Anita Rios for her two-year term. The council also welcomed Junior Council Member Sophie Wynn, she served a one-year term.
FEBRUARY
Lino Lakes public safety director retires
The city of Lino Lakes said goodbye to longtime Public Safety Director John Swenson after almost 15 years. Swenson, who grew up in St. Paul, served in law enforcement and public safety for almost four decades. Swenson became public safety director for the city in 2011. “The staff here in Lino Lakes is second to none,” Swenson said. “I thoroughly have enjoyed working with the staff and continuing to grow the organization to perform at such a high level of service delivery.”
National Honors Society welcomes new members
Multiple students from Centennial High School were inducted into the National Honors Society. The National Honors Society empowers and equips students with the knowledge and skills to be informative leaders in their school, community and beyond.
Centerville Lions put on annual fishing contest
Hundreds of anglers gathered on Centerville Lake and tried their luck on the ice during the Centerville Lions ice fishing contest in February. This year, the Lions celebrated 40 years of hosting the contest. The money raised during the tournament allows the Lions to purchase books for elementary schools, help families in need and more.
Cougar dance teams earns state trip
The Centennial Dance Team (CDT) got the chance to compete at state meet after placing second in Jazz and third in High Kick in the Section 3AAA meet. The top three teams advance to state at Target Center. The CDT is coached by Sarah Austin.
MARCH
Akpan dominates at state for title
Nora Akpan, Centennial junior, cruised to the state wrestling championship at the Xcel Energy Center. Competing at 130 pounds, Akpan finished the season 30-0. She was ranked No. 1 by the Guillotine and lived up to it. Asked if she expected to be state champ, Akpan said, “Yes. I was going to be on the wall,” referring to the display of state champion at the high school. She placed third at state last year at 130 pounds with a 30-3 record.
Centennial Robotics Team finishes 3rd in 54-team field
The Centennial High School Robotics Team, The Centurions, competed at the FIRST Robotics Northern Lights Competition and placed third overall. The team competed against 54 other teams from eight different states. The third-place finish is the best finish in program history, and an improvement over the team’s eighth-place finish last year at the competition.
Chipotle restaurant a possibility at Lexington Retail Center
A public hearing was held at a Lexington City Hall to discuss an application to install a Chipotle at the Lexington Retail Center, also known as Northway Mall. The application was submitted by Menlo Capital Partners and reviewed by the Lexington Planning and Zoning Commission. Multiple residents shared their opinions about the development. Some stating the city does not need a “big business” like Chipotle.
9th annual Guns N Hoses charity hockey games raises funds for first responders
A standing room only crowd packed into Rink 4 at the Blaine Super Rink to watch the ninth annual Guns N Hoses charity hockey game. The Guns beat the Hoses 3-to-1, snapping the Hoses’ winning streak. The event raised nearly $40,000 for first responders.
APRIL
Centennial Middle School performs ‘Matilda Jr.’
Centennial Middle School presented its spring musical, “Matilda Jr.” at the Centennial Middle School Auditorium. There were 86 students in the cast and crew. “Matilda Jr.” is an ode to the anarchy of childhood and the power of imagination. The story follows Matilda, a girl who dreams of a better life, and the children she inspires.
‘Bingo and Bling’ help raise funds for students
The Chain of Lakes Rotary held its annual fundraiser at the Peder Pedersen Pavilion in Hugo. Funds made from the event went towards scholarships for students at Centennial High School.
Cougar lacrosse kicks of season undefeated
The Centennial boys lacrosse team kicked of their season 3-0. The defeated Spring Lake Park by 19-6. Their first two wins were each by one goal. Over the course of those three games, Solomon Marshall netted five goals on eight shots and made two assists. Gavin Cunningham had three goals and an assist, and Gavin Krage two goals and an assist. Macin Hehir scored his first two varsity goals, and Rocco Scarella and Nolan Larson each got their first. Alex Koehn logged his first varsity win as a goaltender.
‘The Addams Family’ comes to life at Centennial High School
The Centennial Theatre Department brought the Addams family to life during its spring musical at the Centennial High School Performing Arts Center. “The Addams Family” musical focused on Wednesday Addams. She ends up falling in love with a sweet and smart young man named Lucas Beineke. Wednesday asks her father, Gomez, not to tell her mother, Morticia, about her boyfriend. Meanwhile, other family members discover Wednesday’s love.
MAY
Centennial School District announces Hall of Fame Class of 2025
Mehmet Konar-Steenberg and Charlene Behne were honored as the newest members of the Centennial Hall of Fame during a ceremony at Infinite Campus. Behne (1960-1993) was recognized for her distinguished service within the district. She was hired three years after the creation of the district and named by her peers as the first “Teacher of the Year” in the district. Konar-Steenberg (Class of 1987) was inducted for being a distinguished alumnus.
Centennial District staff recognized for their service
Two Centennial School District nutrition employees were recognized by the Minnesota School Nutrition Association (MSNA) for their service. Barbi King, food service assistant for Centennial Middle School, was named the Midwest region Employee of the Year. Donna Walter, cook manager at Centerville Elementary School, was recognized by the MSNA as the Minnesota Manager of the Year.
Lino Lakes welcomes new chief of police, fire chief
Earlier this year, Citygate Associates presented its final recommendations, advising the Lino Lakes City Council to restructure the city’s Public Safety Department into independent police and fire departments. This proposed change meant that two new leadership roles would need to be established: chief of police and fire chief, who would oversee their respective departments. Mayor Rob Rafferty inducted Curt Boehme as the new chief of police and Dan L’Allier as the fire chief.
New girls club of Centennial focuses on women empowerment
Centennial High School juniors Brielle Reynolds and Jenna Orcutt are responsible for the creation of The Girls Club, a club that revolves around learning more about women’s history and their future. Reynolds and Orcutt created the club because there wasn’t one at school, where girls could come together, do service projects and work with the community. They also wanted to create a safe space for freshmen through senior girls to be able to connect.
JUNE
A trip down memory lane
Centennial High School seniors experienced a blast from the past and visited their old elementary school, Rice Lake Elementary, before attending graduation at Roy Wilkins Auditorium on the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities campus.
Zins earns trip to state tournament
Brady Zins, Centennial sophomore, played his best golf of the season at Section 5AAA and earned a spot in the state tournament being held at Bunker Hills. Zins opened with a 77, tying his season best, and closed with a par 72, for a 149 total, tying for fifth place, May 27 and 29, at Bunker Hills. In conference play, Zins shot 77 twice, 78, 79 twice and 80.
Centennial girls flag football has strong finish
The Centennial girls flag football team had a strong inaugural season, finishing 13-2. In the state tournament, the girls were able to make it to the semifinals. The state tournament was held on at TCO Stadium.
Lino Lakes makes progress on treatment plant
Construction continued on Lino Lakes’ new water treatment plant at 6590 12th Ave. In June, the contractor completed the detention tanks and filter walkways before beginning construction on the precast wall panels on the western half of the building. The facility will help remove iron and manganese from the City’s water supply, providing safe drinking water to the community.
JULY
Local mayor receives highest honor for elected city officials
Circle Pines Mayor Dave Bartholomay received the C.C. Ludwig Award, presented by the League of Minnesota Cities. The award is the highest honor for elected city officials in the state. The C.C. Ludwig Award was established in 1962 and is named for Clarence C. Ludwig, who served as the League’s executive director from 1935-1959. The award is presented to a city official for their vision, statesmanship and commitment to the public good.
Centerville welcomes new City Administrator
Athanasia Lewis was named Centerville’s next city administrator. The city conducted an extensive hiring process led by GMP, a firm that specializes in municipal searches. After interviewing three finalists, the city council unanimously voted to offer the position to Lewis. Before stepping into her role, Lewis served as interim city administrator since mid-February. Previously, she served as Centerville’s assistant city administrator for three years, assistant city administrator for Collierville, Tennessee and town administrator for Atoka, Tennessee.
Lexington fire chief retires after 19 years
Lexington Fire Chief Erik Edwards retired in 2025 after almost two decades of service. Edwards was sworn in as chief of the Lexington Fire Department in 2021. He joined the department in 2006 and served as captain for eight years before becoming chief.
Fete De Lacs ‘America the Beautiful’
This year’s Fete des Lacs celebration boasted the theme, “American the Beautiful.” Festivities for 2025 included a public safety night, Main Street Market and Bald Eagle Waterski Show, fireworks, parade, Kids Fest and more.
AUGUST
Centennial Lakes is Little League state champion
The Centennial Lakes Little League (CLLL) 12-and-under all-star team captured the state championship July 25-27 on their home field, advancing to the Midwest Regionals in Indianapolis. At the state tournament, CLLL beat their long-time arch rival St. Louis Park 8-1 in the semifinals and again 6-2 in the final. They had opened with a 12-2 win over Blaine. All that action took place at Carl Eck Field in Lino Lakes. The CLLL lost twice at Regionals, to the North Dakota champion 10-4 and to the Nebraska champion 10-5. The experience included playing on television (ESPN Plus).
Rotary member helps collect paper bags for the food shelf
Chain of Lakes Rotary Member Mary Wynne collected brown paper grocery bags to donate to the Centennial Community Food Shelf. A Rotary member for 3 1/2 years, Wynne was conversing with a friend when she said she wanted to do something meaningful in the community. Shortly afterward, she visited the Centennial Community Food Shelf and saw volunteers placing four brown paper bags in grocery carts for shoppers to use. “What can I do to help you guys out?” she asked. In six weeks, Wynne was able to collect over 400 bags.
Better together: Night to Unite creates connections
Members of the Lino Lakes Fire Department and the Lino Lakes Police Department stopped at multiple neighborhood block parties to celebrate Night to Unite. Night to Unite is a statewide event that builds bonds among communities and public safety organizations, such as local fire departments and law enforcement agencies. The annual celebration occurs on the first Tuesday in August. Residents and public safety personnel gathered to promote safe communities.
Meet the 2025-2026 Miss Lino Lakes Ambassadors
Ella Friedman, Sofia Taylor and Delilah LeClair are the Lino Lakes Ambassadors for 2025-2026. Seven candidates vied for three spots in the Miss Lino Lakes Ambassador program, which was established in 2004 as part of Blue Heron Days. The ambassadors represent the city at parades, coronations, volunteer events and fundraisers throughout the Twin Cities. The city said the program’s goal is to empower young women by giving them opportunities to be leaders, strengthen their communication skills and build their confidence.
SEPTEMBER
Blaine welcomes new State Emergency Operations Center
The new State Emergency Operations Center opened in Blaine. State, local and federal agencies will coordinate responses to disaster, emergencies or terrorist events at the center. The governor, state director of emergency management and homeland security and multiple agencies will direct state representatives from the center when responding to and recovering from an event. The new center is located at 3925 Pheasant Ridge Drive.
Centennial Fire District takes ‘big step’ to integrate with SBM
The Centennial Fire District, and the cities it serves, continued to strengthen its partnership with the Spring Lake Park - Blaine - Mounds View Fire Department. This year, SBM offered Circle Pines and Centerville the opportunity to contract for all fire services. SBM has provided leadership services to the Centennial Fire District. Centennial has remained its own entity, with its own firefighters and equipment, he said, but SBM provides a fire chief and managerial services. In return, the Centennial Fire District helps train SBM firefighters on emergency medical technician services.
Disc golf course comes to Centerville park
Centerville and surrounding area residents saw some new changes to Laurie LaMotte Park, including the addition of a disc golf course. The park also received a new playground. The idea for the course was originally presented by Centerville native Devin Grahek to the city’s Parks and Recreation Committee at its November 2024 meeting. The disc golf course a Laurie LaMotte Park features a practice basket, located between the playground and skatepark, and is nine holes.
Blue Heron receives ‘best elementary school’ title
Each year, Press Publications hosts the Reader’s Choice Best of the Press Contest, asking locals to vote for their favorites, ranging from the best cup of coffee to the best florist and everything in between. Rising to the top of the “Best Elementary School” category in the Quad area is Blue Heron Elementary School, located in Lino Lakes. The school opened in the fall of 2002 and is one of eight elementary schools within the Centennial School District. The name Blue Heron was chosen to reflect the history of blue herons within the Lino Lakes community.
OCTOBER
New childhood development program offers outdoor learning
Centennial Early Childhood, in partnership with the Wargo Nature Center, has launched a new program called Outdoor Explorers Preschool. The program gives preschoolers the opportunity to explore nature and learn through hands-on outdoor experiences. To start class, preschoolers play outside for an hour in a designated playground before heading inside to do circle time, journaling and take a snack break. Molly Wrobel, who teaches the program, said the class will also go on an adventure, whether that is raking leaves or walking to a bridge by the center.
Klein caps strong career
Lauren Klein, Centennial’s No. 1 singles player, closed out her prep career with her first state tournament appearance after finishing runner-up in Section 7AAA singles. At state, Klein placed 10th out of 16 qualifiers in Class 3A singles. “Qualifying for the state tournament has been a goal of mine since I started on the team in eighth grade,” said Klein.
Scarecrow Crawl kicks off
In honor of Halloween, The Rookery in Lino Lakes put on a scarecrow crawl. Participants decorated their scarecrow and placed it along the path at The Rookery. Rookery members and visitors were able to walk down the path and vote for their favorite scarecrow leading up to Halloween night.
Church continues holiday bazaar tradition
Since the 1950’s, St. Mark’s Lutheran Church in Circle Pines has hosted a holiday bazaar that includes vendors, a bake sale, raffle, a white elephant sale, food and more. This year’s bazaar took take place on Saturday, Nov. 8. This year featured 20 vendors. Vendor booths included woodworking, jewelry, crotchet and knit items and handmade fedora hats. There also was chili for lunch, provided by the St. Mark’s choir, and dessert provided by the church’s social ministry team.
NOVEMBER
Cougars head to state
The Centennial Cougars entered this season looking like a contender for a state trip, with a tall and agile lineup including six of their top eight back from a 19-12 team that lost a close section final to Anoka. During their regular reason, the team had had eight losses to teams that average 24 wins, but the Cougars (22-8) are in the big show after defeating Andover 25-18, 25-17, 25-12 in the Section 7AAAA finals at home. The Cougars then went on to face Prior Lake at Grand Casino Arena in St. Paul at the state tournament.
Rice Lake Elementary students honor veterans
In honor of Veterans Day, students at Rice Lake Elementary honored family members that have served, past or present, by posting photos of them on the Wall of Honor. On Veterans Day, the school honored veterans with a short parade inside the school followed by a gathering for visits and students. The Wall of Honor was organized by Rice Lake Elementary’s Parent Teacher Organization.
Minnesota senator visits Circle Pines
The Circle Pines City Council received a visit from Senator Heather Gustafson (DFL) regarding the upcoming 2026 Legislative Session. Gustafson also presented a Minnesota Senate Resolution recognizing Circle Pines Mayor Dave Bartholomay for his decades of service in Circle Pines. Bartholomay served as the city’s mayor for 20 years. Before becoming mayor, he served as a member of the City Council for four years.
Circle Pines hosts environmental family fun night
The city of Circle Pines and the Environmental Stewardship Committee held a family fun night at the Centennial Library that revolved around the city’s Environmental Stewardship Plan. The event featured a visit from the University of Minnesota Raptor Center, a story time and crafts. The plan was created to outline various ways the community can work together to help shared natural resources.
DECEMBER
Centennial High School reimagines vampire novella
The Centennial Theater Company brought its own version of “Carmilla” to life for their fall show. In 1872, a Gothic novella written by Irish author Joseph Sheridan le Fanu was published. The novella was titled “Carmilla” and is one of the earliest known works of vampire fiction. Le Fanue’s vampires are women and is regarded as one of the most influential vampire stories of all time. Senior AJ Basara played vampire Carmilla.
Coach Diggins retires
Mike Diggins, who has spent most of his life associated with Centennial football, will be just a Cougar fan from now on. Diggins announced at the end of the season that he will retire from coaching after 15 years as head coach, 37 years on the staff and 45 years total in coaching. Two years after reaching the apex of coaching with his Cougars winning the Class 6A championship, Diggins, 61, called it a career.
Long time Mayor reflects on decades of public service
At the end of the year, Dave Bartholomay stepped down from his role as Circle Pines mayor after almost 25 years in local government. Bartholomay decided to run for city council in 2001 after he and his wife, Janis, attended a Circle Pines City Council meeting about a potential development. After four years on the council, he ran for mayor in 2006 and has held the position ever since.
Lino Lakes welcomes new Aldi Grocery Store
The Aldi grocery store located at 7085 Otter Lake Road in Lino Lakes, near the border of Hugo, officially opened to the public. The store is approximately 19,437 square feet. Its main access is at Main Street and 70th Street. It is open 9 a.m.- 8 p.m. Monday through Sunday.
